t: Job 38
The Lord Speaks
Then*p the Lord*s spoke to Job out of the storm. He said:
“Who*pn is this that obscures my plans with*ld words without knowledge?
Brace*ln yourself like a man; I*ld will question you, and*ld you shall answer me.
“Where*pn were you when I laid the earth’s foundation? Tell*ld me, if you understand.
Who*ln marked off its dimensions? Surely you know! Who*ld stretched a measuring line across it?
On*ln what were its footings set, or*ld who laid its cornerstone—
while*ln the morning stars sang together and*ld all the angels shouted for joy?
“Who*pn shut up the sea behind doors when*ld it burst forth from the womb,
when*ln I made the clouds its garment and*ld wrapped it in thick darkness,
when*ln I fixed limits for it and*ld set its doors and bars in place,
when*ln I said, ‘This far you may come and no farther; here*ld is where your proud waves halt’?
“Have*pn you ever given orders to the morning, or*ld shown the dawn its place,
that*ln it might take the earth by the edges and*ld shake the wicked out of it?
The*ln earth takes shape like clay under a seal; its*ld features stand out like those of a garment.
The*ln wicked are denied their light, and*ld their upraised arm is broken.
“Have*pn you journeyed to the springs of the sea or*ld walked in the recesses of the deep?
Have*ln the gates of death been shown to you? Have*ld you seen the gates of the deepest darkness?
Have*ln you comprehended the vast expanses of the earth? Tell*ld me, if you know all this.
“What*pn is the way to the abode of light? And*ld where does darkness reside?
Can*ln you take them to their places? Do*ld you know the paths to their dwellings?
Surely*ln you know, for you were already born! You*ld have lived so many years!
“Have*pn you entered the storehouses of the snow or*ld seen the storehouses of the hail,
which*ln I reserve for times of trouble, for*ld days of war and battle?
What*ln is the way to the place where the lightning is dispersed, or*ld the place where the east winds are scattered over the earth?
Who*ln cuts a channel for the torrents of rain, and*ld a path for the thunderstorm,
to*ln water a land where no one lives, an*ld uninhabited desert,
to*ln satisfy a desolate wasteland and*ld make it sprout with grass?
Does*ln the rain have a father? Who*ld fathers the drops of dew?
From*ln whose womb comes the ice? Who*ld gives birth to the frost from the heavens
when*ln the waters become hard as stone, when*ld the surface of the deep is frozen?
“Can*pn you bind the chains of the Pleiades? Can*ld you loosen Orion’s belt?
Can*ln you bring forth the constellations in their seasons or*ld lead out the Bear with its cubs?
Do*ln you know the laws of the heavens? Can*ld you set up God’s dominion over the earth?
“Can*pn you raise your voice to the clouds and*ld cover yourself with a flood of water?
Do*ln you send the lightning bolts on their way? Do*ld they report to you, ‘Here we are’?
Who*ln gives the ibis wisdom or*ld gives the rooster understanding?
Who*ln has the wisdom to count the clouds? Who*ld can tip over the water jars of the heavens
when*ln the dust becomes hard and*ld the clods of earth stick together?
“Do*pn you hunt the prey for the lioness and*ld satisfy the hunger of the lions
when*ln they crouch in their dens or*ld lie in wait in a thicket?
Who*ln provides food for the raven when*ld its young cry out to God and*ld wander about for lack of food?
